question: To make the fossil fuel supply last longer, should electricity use be reduced or increased?

content.source_1: Most of the worldâ€™s electricity is generated by burning fossil fuels (coal, oil, and natural gas), so electricity demand directly drives fossil fuel consumption in the power sector.
content.source_2: When electricity demand falls on fossil-fuel-dependent grids, fossil-fired power plants reduce output, which means less coal, oil, and natural gas are burned.
content.source_3: For a finite resource, the plan that reduces its rate of consumption the most will make the remaining supply last the longest.
content.source_4: Electric vehicles and electric heat pumps deliver the same transport and heating services using far less energy than gasoline cars and gas furnaces; as a result, broad electrification of these end uses lowers total fossil fuel consumption even if total electricity use increases.
content.source_5: A substantial and growing share of electricity generation comes from non-fossil sources (renewables and nuclear), and added non-fossil generation typically displaces fossil-fired generation.
content.source_6: Transport and building heating together account for a large share of end-use energy currently supplied by fossil fuels in major economies, so electrifying these services has an outsized effect on total fossil fuel demand.
